category.name: Website Usability
category.description: Fewer barriers for users to achieve their goals. It can also be called a trusting relationship between the user and the product.

link.title: The 7 most important UX KPIs and how to measure them

metrics.name: Task Success Rate
metrics.description: Users will give up on their goals if they feel distrustful of the product or if it is too complicated to operate before they achieve their goals.

metrics.name: Time-on-Task
metrics.description: The time to complete a goal is affected by how few operations are required to do so and the ease of understanding.

metrics.name: Search vs Navigation
metrics.description: What makes users happy is not that they control the product to get the information they need, but that it falls from the sky on its own.

metrics.name: System Usability Scale
metrics.description: Asking users directly is one way to get quick tips. (That's just the subjective aspect though.)

metrics.name: Customer Satisfaction
metrics.description: Asking questions about the user's feelings could be helpful in determining the direction of improvement methods. Devilish methods could be avoided.

category.name: Development Performance
category.description: How much and how accurately the development team can do its job is the power to improve the product.

link.title: Use Four Keys metrics like change failure rate to measure your DevOps performance | Google Cloud Blog

metrics.name: Time to Restore Service
metrics.description: A method must be established to get the product out of a tight spot. We should not be in a hurry to start the recovery process, but rather follow a set procedure and start the recovery process in a good, prepared environment.

metrics.name: Change Failure Rate
metrics.description: Consider ways to increase the accuracy of testing and the likelihood that errors can be detected before release. This is not craftsmanship.

metrics.name: Lead Time for Changes
metrics.description: Once a method of improvement is determined, it must be immediately reflected in the product. It may be a good time to wait for the mechanical process over a cup of coffee, though.

metrics.name: Deployment Frequency
metrics.description: A team that can make 10 changes in the same amount of time versus a team that can make 100 may have a 10-fold difference in the likelihood of a good product.

category.name: Team Effectiveness
category.description: If the psychological aspect of the team is not fulfilled, nothing can begin. It is important to focus not on the team members, but on the relationship between them.

metrics.name: Impact
metrics.description: Congrats to everyone for their contributions against the team. Please listen.

metrics.name: Psychological Safety
metrics.description: If there is nothing to fear as you work, you can focus on what is most important to the product.

metrics.name: Dependability
metrics.description: Responding with a smile when asked for help is as easy as creating a library with an easy-to-understand API.

metrics.name: Structure and Clarity
metrics.description: When everyone knows what they are supposed to do and who their role is, there is no need for daily instructions.

metrics.name: Meaning
metrics.description: Define a useful product for people. Then, gather members who agree with it.
